info.title: Importing TLS server certificates and keys

sect1.para: You can manage your CA certificates and keys for 389 Directory Server with the following command line tools: certutil, openssl, and pk12util.
For testing purposes, you can use the self-signed certificate that dscreate creates when you create a new 389Â DS instance. Find the certificate at /etc/dirsrv/slapd-INSTANCE-NAME/ca.crt.

For production environments, it is a best practice to use a third-party certificate authority, such as Let's Encrypt, CAcert.org, SSL.com, or whatever CA you choose. Request a server certificate, a client certificate, and a root certificate.

important.para: The Mozilla NSS (Network Security Services) toolkit uses nicknames for certificates in the certificate store. The server certificate uses the nickname Server-Cert.

step.para: Use the following commands to remove the Self-Signed-CA and Server-Cert from the instance:
Replace INSTANCE_NAME with the instance name of the directory server. This is LDAP1 in the previous sections.
Import the CA that has signed your certificate.

screen.command: sudo dsctl INSTANCE_NAME tls import-ca /path/to/CA/in/PEM/format/CA.pem NICKNAME_FOR_CA

step.para: Replace INSTANCE_NAME with the instance name of the directory server. Replace /path/to/CA/in/PEM/format/CA.pem with the full path to the CA certificate file in PEM format. Replace NICKNAME_FOR_CA with a nickname for the CA.
Import the server certificate and the key for the certificate.

Replace INSTANCE_NAME with the instance name of the directory server. Replace /path/to/SERVER.pem with the full path to the server certificate in PEM format. Replace /path/to/SERVER.key with the full path to the server certificate key file in PEM format.
Restart the instance so that the new certificates are used.
Replace INSTANCE_NAME with the instance name of the directory server.
